intro: Dodecatheon dentatum subsp. ellisiae, commonly known as the Ellisia's five-petaled bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Primulaceae family and is characterized by its distinctive bell-shaped flowers that typically range in color from white to pink. The subspecies is distinguished by its finely toothed leaves and a shorter corolla compared to other members of the species. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. The plant produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small seeds, which are dispersed by wind.
